questions.question: Explore how coding hours and AI usage interact across different levels of code complexity to identify any distinct workload profiles.

answer.value: The exploration reveals at least three workload profiles: light (low complexity), balanced/diverse (mid complexity), and two types of heavy (high complexity with high or low AI).

key_insights: With fewer dimensions, the remaining three axes (AI usage, Hours_Coded, Code_Complexity) show clearer trends: as complexity increases, hours tend to rise slightly, but AI usage variation widens.
At low complexity (scores 0–3), most points have low to moderate AI usage (0–20%) and hours below 10.
At mid complexity (4–7), hours spread from 6 to 14, and AI usage covers the full range (0–50%), suggesting diverse strategies.
Lines now cluster by complexity score first. For each complexity level, the fan-out to hours and AI usage reveals distinct profiles.
High complexity scores (8–10) consistently pair with high hours (12+), but AI usage splits: one subset uses AI heavily (~40%), another uses little (~10%).
High complexity scores (8–10) consistently pair with high hours (12+), but AI usage splits: one subset uses AI heavily (~40%), another uses little (~10%).
High complexity scores (8–10) consistently pair with high hours (12+), but AI usage splits: one subset uses AI heavily (~40%), another uses little (~10%).

reasoning.reasoning: Hiding extra dimensions reduces visual clutter, making it easier to trace interactions among the three core metrics.

Reordering by complexity groups developers by technical demand. This clarifies that high complexity always requires long hours, but AI adoption varies—suggesting two different high-complexity strategies.
